S1381-1169(14)00425-7 10.1016/j.molcata.2014.09.022 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 XRD patterns of the samples. (♦) BaCO3, (■) Ru, (□) RuO2, (●) Ce0.33Zr0.67O2, (▴) Al2O3. Fig. 2 TEM and SAED images of Pt/Ba/ACZ (a, c and e) and Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ (b, d and f). Fig. 3 NO x evolution as a function of time during lean/rich cycle after reaching a steady state. (a) Pt/Ba/ACZ; (b) Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ. Reaction conditions: catalyst mass=0.5g, total flow rate=600mL/min, GHSV=72,000cm3/(gh). Lean atmosphere: 750ppm NO/10% O2/balance N2, time=5min; rich atmosphere: 5% H2/balance N2, time=2min. Fig. 4 H2-TPR profiles of fresh samples. Fig. 5 Ce 3d XPS spectra of Pt/Ba/ACZ, Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ, Pt/ACZ and Pt–Ru/ACZ. Fig. 6 in situ DRIFTS spectra collected after exposure to NO/O2/N2 for different time at 200°C. (a) Pt/Ba/ACZ; (b) Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ. Fig. 7 in situ DRIFTS spectra collected after exposure to NO/O2/N2 for 20min at different temperatures. (a) Pt/Ba/ACZ; (b) Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ. Table 1 Textural properties and surface Ce/Zr ratio of all samples. Sample S BET (m2/g) Pore radius (nm) Pores volume (cm3/g) Ce/Zr a Pt/ACZ 190 2.42 0.28 0.41 Pt–Ru/ACZ 206 2.68 0.36 0.52 Pt/Ba/ACZ 133 2.48 0.23 – Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ 139 2.81 0.28 – a Determined by XPS. Table 2 NSC (μmol/g) in 60min at different temperatures. Sample 200°C 250°C 300°C 350°C 400°C Pt/Ba/ACZ 330 366 385 337 244 Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ 282 408 446 365 263 Pt–Ru/Ba/Al2O3–Ce0.33Zr0.67O2: An effective catalyst for NO x storage and reduction Zhilin Chen a b Xiuyun Wang a Yuling Wang a Ruihu Wang a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Structural Chemistry, Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter, Key Laboratory of Coal to Ethylene Glycol and Its Related Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Fuzhou, Fujian 350002, China State Key Laboratory of Structural Chemistry, Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter, Key Laboratory of Coal to Ethylene Glycol and Its Related Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences Fuzhou Fujian 350002 China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 591 83711028; fax: +86 591 83714946. Graphical abstract Pt–Ru/Ba/Al2O3–Ce0.33Zr0.67O2 shows superior performances in NO x storage and reduction to Pt/Ba/Al2O3–Ce0.33Zr0.67O2. The addition of Ru has resulted in decrement of the reduction temperature of Pt and the transformation temperature of NO x storage route from nitrite to nitrate. An effective catalyst of NO x storage and reduction (NSR), Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ (ACZ=Al2O3–Ce0.33Zr0.67O2), has been presented through using ACZ as a support. The catalyst was well characterized by XRD, TEM, N2 physisorption, H2-TPR and XPS. Ce0.33Zr0.67 solid solution was formed in the catalyst. The effects of Ru addition on NSR performances were investigated. In comparison with Pt/Ba/ACZ, the addition of Ru in Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ drops the reduction temperature of Pt, an obvious promoting effect on NSR was observed above 200°C. The presence of 5vol% CO2 in feed gas shows an inhibiting effect on NO x storage and reduction. Keywords Ceria Environmental chemistry NO x storage and reduction NO x removal Ruthenium 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxide (NO x ) as one of the major air pollutants has considerable negative effects on environment and human health [1]. One of the main sources of NO x is the burning of fossil fuels in automotive engines [2]. With more and more stringent regulations concerning NO x emission, much attention has been paid to catalytic control techniques for decontaminating automobile emission [3,4]. Among NO x post-treatment techniques, traditional three-way catalysts are effective for gasoline-powered engines, but they are incapable of reducing NO x to N2 under oxygen-rich conditions, which are encountered in lean-burn engines [4,5]. NO x storage and reduction (NSR) technique is considered to be a dominating approach to abatement of NO x from lean-burn engines. Pt/Ba/Al2O3 is commonly used as a model NSR catalyst, which works under fuel-lean and fuel-rich cyclic conditions. During lean conditions, NO is oxidized into NO2 on platinum, and is then stored on barium as nitrates/nitrites, when periodically switched to rich conditions, the stored nitrates/nitrites are decomposed and the released NO x are eventually reduced into N2 on platinum [6,7]. One of disadvantages of Pt/Ba/Al2O3 is connected with deactivation caused by thermal aging [8]. Thus, the development of NSR catalysts with high thermal stability and good NSR performance is still a great challenge. Supports are well known to have important effect on structures and properties of NSR catalysts. Alumina has been widely used as a support in order to achieve favorable dispersion and valid utilization of active metals and barium species [9]. However, solid-solid reaction between barium and alumina can generate inactive barium aluminates, which are much more stable under typical operating conditions [10]. The addition of a promoter in alumina is considered as an attractive strategy to increase thermal stability of the catalysts. Ceria is reported to improve stability of the support through inhibiting formation of inactive barium aluminates [11]. The use of ceria–zirconia composites can form ceria–zirconia solid solution, which can further increase thermal stability and surface properties [12]. It is known that catalytic activity is closely related to the surface area of support, ceria–zirconia solid solution with the ratio of 1:2 was reported to possess the highest surface area [13]. The alumina-supported ceria–zirconia (ACZ) has been widely used as a support in three-way catalysts, but the application of ACZ as a support in NSR is seldom investigated [14]. Pt-based catalysts have been extensively utilized in NSR. Substituting a single noble metal with bimetal or alloy systems is regarded as a valid approach to develop highly efficient catalytic systems. The combination of Pt with other metals, such as Co, Fe, La and Rh, has been reported to enhance NSR performances of the catalysts. Ruthenium-based materials have been applied in NO x oxidation or reduction [15,16]. It was found that Pt–Ru bimetallic catalysts possess better catalytic performances than their monometallic counterparts owing to ensemble effects between Pt and Ru [17]. Pt–Ru bimetallic system was reported to show superior catalytic activity in the oxidation of carbon monoxide and selective hydrogenation, but their application in NSR has not been reported hitherto [18,19]. In our continuous effort to seek highly stable and efficient NSR catalysts, herein, we report synthesis and properties of Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ (ACZ=Al2O3–Ce0.33Zr0.67O2) [20,21]. As a comparison, Pt/Ba/ACZ was also investigated. Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ shows superior NSR performances over Pt/Ba/ACZ, the influence of Ru addition on the structure and NSR performance was explored. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Al(NO3)3·9H2O, Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, RuCl3, H2O2 (30%) and NH3·H2O (25–28%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. Ba(OAc)2, Zr(NO3)4·5H2O and H2PtCl6·6H2O were purchased from J&K Scientific Ltd. All chemicals were used without further purification. Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ and Pt/Ba/ACZ were synthesized via parallel flow co-precipitation method [22]. Al(NO3)3·9H2O, Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, Zr(NO3)4·5H2O, H2PtCl6·6H2O and H2O2 (30%) were dissolved in distilled water. The molar ratio of Ce to Zr was 1:2, and the total content of Ce and Zr as CeO2 and ZrO2 against ACZ was 21wt%, the nominal platinum loading against ACZ was 1wt%. The above solution was heated at 60°C for 20min, the solution and the diluted ammonia were simultaneously added into water (50mL) by longer pump with vigorous stirring at 60°C, and the final pH of the solution was about 9. The resultant mixture was stirred for additional 1h, centrifuged, and washed with distilled water until pH=7. The obtained solid was re-dispersed in water (100mL) and stirred for 3h. The aqueous RuCl3 solution and the excess diluted ammonia were simultaneously added to the mixture by longer pump with vigorous stirring at 60°C. The nominal ruthenium loading against ACZ was 5wt%. The mixture was aged for additional 4h and then centrifuged, washed with distilled water until pH=7. The solids were dried at 100°C overnight, and then calcined at 500°C for 4h. The resultant sample was denoted as Pt–Ru/ACZ. Ba was loaded on Pt–Ru/ACZ by impregnation method using aqueous Ba(OAc)2. The amount of theoretical Ba loading against Pt–Ru/ACZ was 16wt%. The mixture was dried at 100°C overnight, calcined at 300°C for 4h. The resultant sample was denoted as fresh Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ. The preparation of fresh Pt/Ba/ACZ (1wt% Pt, 16wt% Ba) was similar to that of fresh Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ except the absence of ruthenium. To enable characterization conditions of the samples to be closer to NSR test conditions, fresh Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ and Pt/Ba/ACZ were pretreated in a gas flow of 5vol% H2 with N2 balance at 500°C for 4h, and then cooled to room temperature for XRD, N2 physisorption and XPS analysis. The resultant samples were denoted as Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ and Pt/Ba/ACZ, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) experiments were recorded on a Miniflex II diffractometer using Cu-Kα radiation (λ =1.5406Å) in the range of 2θ from 5 to 85°. The assignment of the crystalline phases was based on the file cards of JCPDS powder diffraction. Specific surface area was determined from N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm at −196°C on a Micrometrics ASAP 2020 adsorption apparatus. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation was used to calculate specific surface area. The Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method was applied to determine pore structure. Temperature-programmed reduction of H2 (H2-TPR) was conducted on an AutoChem 2920 instrument equipped with a TCD detector. The samples (50mg) were pretreated under an air flow (30mL/min) at 500°C for 30min, followed by purging with Ar (30mL/min) at the same temperature for 30min and cooled down to 65°C. Then, a flow of 10vol% H2 in Ar (30mL/min) was switched to the system, and the sample was heated from 65 to 800°C at a rate of 10°C/min. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was carried out on a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250 machine fitted with a micro-focused, monochromatic Al Kα source (Kα =1486.6eV), and a charge neutralizer was equipped in the instrument. The surface charging effect was corrected by adjusting the binding energy of C1s signal as 284.6eV. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) measurements were carried out with a JEM-2010 microscope operating at 200kV in the mode of bright field. in situ Diffuse reflection infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) was recorded on a Nicolet Nexus FT-IR spectrometer in the range of 650–4000cm−1 with 32 scans at a resolution of 4cm−1. In a DRIFTS cell, a sample was firstly pretreated with nitrogen at 400°C for 30min and then cooled to 50°C. After the background spectrum was recorded, a mixture gas NO/O2/N2 was introduced to sample cell, and spectra were immediately recorded at different exposure time. 2.3 Catalyst activity measurement Catalytic activity tests were carried out in a stainless steel reactor (internal diameter=8mm) with a fixed bed. A 0.5g of fresh sample was pretreated in a gas flow of 5vol% H2 with N2 balance from room temperature to 500°C with the rate of 5°C/min, hold at 500°C for 4h, and then was cooled to test temperature. The activity test was carried out in the temperature range from 200 to 400°C. The inlet gas mixture was 750ppm NO/10vol% O2/N2 balance for lean conditions and 5vol% H2/N2 balance for rich conditions. The feed gas was introduced using mass-flow controllers at a total flow rate of 600mL/min, corresponding to a space velocity of 72,000h−1. The outlet gas (NO, NO2 and NO x ) concentrations were determined by an on-line chemiluminescence NO x analyzer (Model 42i-HL, Thermo Scientific). N2 selectivity was analyzed using a GC7820 analyzer. NO x storage capacity (NSC) was calculated according to the following formula after reaching a steady state [23]. NSC = NO x inlet × V × t N 0 × m × storage ratio × 10 − 3 = 40.2 × t × storage ratio ( mmol / g catalyst ) Here, NO x is the concentration in ppm unit, V is the flow rate of feed gas, i.e. 600mL/min, N 0 is a constant, i.e. 22.4L/mol, m is the weight of the catalyst, i.e. 0.5g, and storage ratio is the percentage of the amount of the stored NO x to that of the inlet NO x . In order to further investigate NO x reduction performance, 750ppm NO, 5vol% H2 with N2 balance was also introduced as feed gas in the rich period. NO x conversion was calculated according to the following equation: NO x conversion ( % ) = NO x inlet − NO x outlet NO x inlet × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD XRD patterns of the samples are presented in Fig. 1 . For all samples, the characteristic peak of Al2O3 can be clearly observed at 67.1° [JCPDS 10-425], its crystalline structure remains γ-alumina phase. Other peaks at 29.3, 34.2, 49.4 and 58.9° in Pt/ACZ are ascribed to Ce0.33Zr0.67O2 solid solution, which becomes weaker in Pt/Ba/ACZ, Pt–Ru/ACZ and Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ [24]. There is no obvious signal of ZrO2 or CeO2 in the samples, and mutual stabilization of Al2O3 and Ce0.33Zr0.67O2 forms stable composite oxides [11]. The diffraction peaks of BaCO3 at 23.9, 34.2, 42.1, 46.7 and 44.8° were also observed in Pt/Ba/ACZ and Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ owing to the decomposition of Ba(OAc)2 into crystalline BaCO3 during sample calcination [25]. It should be mentioned that the characteristic peaks of RuO2 in Pt–Ru/ACZ can be found at 28.0, 35.2 and 54.3°, but RuO2 transforms into Ru in Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ owing to hydrogen treatment of Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ at 500°C [26]. However, no obvious diffraction peaks of Pt or PtO x were detected in all samples due to fine dispersion and/or low weight loading of Pt [27]. ICP analyses show that Pt contents in Pt/Ba/ACZ and Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ are 0.65 and 0.48%, respectively, and Ru content in Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ is 1.52%. All of them are much lower than the theoretical loading (Table S1). 3.2 TEM TEM images of Pt/Ba/ACZ and Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ are shown in Fig. 2 , the morphology and average size of Pt and/or Ru particles in Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ are similar to Pt particles of Pt/Ba/ACZ. In addition, some small particles were also clearly observed in Pt/Ba/ACZ and Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ (Fig. 2c and d). EDX mapping shows that Pt is associated with Ru in Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ, but the aggregation of partial Ru was observed (Fig. S2). The selected area electron diffraction pattern shows rings in Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ possess the additional bright spots in comparison with that Pt/Ba/ACZ, which is ascribed to the presence of Ru [28]. 3.3 N2 physisorption The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms of all samples give rise to type IV curve with H2-shaped hysteresis loop (Fig. S1), suggesting the presence of wormhole-like mesostructure and interstice mesoporous structure formed by particle assembly [29]. Pt–Ru/ACZ and Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ possess larger hysteresis loops than Pt/ACZ and Pt/Ba/ACZ, respectively. It is known that the size of loops has a positive correlation with pore volume. Thus, the addition of Ru results in increment of specific surface area. As shown in Table 1 , specific surface area, pore radius and pore volume in Pt–Ru/ACZ and Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ are larger than their respective Ru-free counterpart, suggesting the addition of Ru has an obvious effect on the textural properties of the samples. After Pt/ACZ and Pt–Ru/ACZ are impregnated with barium, their specific surface areas are lowered from 190 to 133m2/g and from 206 to 139m2/g, respectively, which is probably caused by partial pore blocking or filling after barium impregnation, resulting in the increment of their pore radius and decrement of pore volumes. 3.4 NO x storage capacity and reduction property Fig. S3 presents NO x storage performances as a function of time at different temperatures. NO x breakthrough profiles of Pt/Ba/ACZ and Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ show similar variation trends. The outlet NO x concentration sharply drops to a minimum value at about 2min, and followed by fast rise and then slow increment. The outlet NO x concentration almost reaches constant in 60min. During the process, NO x is mainly stored on barium species in the form of nitrates and/or nitrites. Obviously, the outlet NO x concentration in Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ is lower than that in Pt/Ba/ACZ, suggesting Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ possess higher NO x storage efficiency than Pt/Ba/ACZ. With increment of time, the outlet NO x concentrations slowly increase due to gradual saturation of storage sites by NO x [30]. The outlet NO x concentrations at 300°C are lowest among test temperatures in Pt/Ba/ACZ and Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ, indicating the highest NO x storage capacity at this temperature, while the highest outlet NO x concentration was observed at 400°C, which is probably attributed to the limited storage of nitrate species at the temperature [31]. It should be noted that the outlet NO x concentrations at 200 and 400°C are similar to each other in Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ. NO x storage capacities (NSC) in 60min at different temperatures are summarized in Table 2 . NSC at 200°C in Pt/Ba/ACZ and Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ are 330 and 282μmol/g, respectively. NSC enhance as temperature increases. The maximum NSC in Pt/Ba/ACZ and Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ are obtained at 300°C, which are consistent with profiles of the outlet NO x concentration. The maximum NSC in Pt/Ba/ACZ and Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ are 385 and 446μmol/g, respectively. Further increment of temperature leads to the decrement of NSC. Their NSC at 400°C are decreased to 244 and 263μmol/g, respectively. The results are in accordance with previous reports on the conventional Pt/Ba/Al2O3 [31a]. Fig. 3 shows NO x evolution as a function of time during 5min lean/2min rich cycle after the catalytic system reaches a steady state. After the catalyst was reduced by 5vol% H2, the outlet NO x concentration of Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ is higher than that of Pt/Ba/ACZ, resulting from higher stored NO x amount of Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ under lean conditions than that of Pt/Ba/ACZ, and the released NO x cannot be totally reduced instantly. After the outlet NO x concentration reaches the maxima, the outlet NO x concentration of Pt/Ba/ACZ in the second minute descends from 335 to 9ppm at 200°C and from 222 to 6ppm at 400°C, while the outlet NO x concentrations in Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ decrease from 640 to 12ppm at 200°C and from 298 to 5ppm at 400°C. It is clear that the decrement of outlet NO x concentration in Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ is more than that of Pt/Ba/ACZ. The relative percentages of the reduced NO x in the rich period to the stored NO x in the lean period are listed in Table S2. The percentages of Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ are higher than that of Pt/Ba/ACZ except at 200°C, indicating better reduction performance of Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ above 200°C. NO x conversions and selectivities at 300°C were also investigated using 750ppm NO and 5vol% H2 with N2 balance as feed gas. NO x conversions in Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ and Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ are 83% and 94%, respectively, and their N2 selectivities are over 99%. In order to clarify the influences of CO2 on NSR performances, 5vol% CO2 was introduced into the feed gas. As shown in Fig. S4, NSC of Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ and Pt/Ba/ACZ are decreased by 9.0% and 15.8%, respectively, which can be attributed to competition adsorption over BaCO3 active sites between CO2 and NO x . As expected, NO x reduction was also significantly inhibited by CO2 owing to the reduction of CO2 by H2 into CO through reverse water gas shift chemistry [32]. 3.5 H2-TPR To further understand the effect of Ru addition on catalytic performances, the reducibility of fresh samples was investigated by H2-TPR experiments. As shown in Fig. 4 , ACZ only possesses a weak peak at 433°C, which is attributed to the reduction of bulk and surface oxygen species [29,33], there is no sign of reduction at low temperature. The reduction peak in fresh Pt/Ba/ACZ occurs at 136°C, whose experimental hydrogen consumption is 133μmol/g, which is much higher than theoretical hydrogen consumption of 67μmol/g required to completely reduce PtO2 into Pt. Most of additional hydrogen consumption is mainly ascribed to hydrogen spillover from metal particles to support surface due to concomitant reduction of Pt–O–Ce. Similar results are also reported in ceria-based materials [34]. Interestingly, fresh Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ possesses two reduction peaks at 87 and 121°C. The experimental hydrogen consumptions of the two reduction peaks are 42 and 497μmol/g, respectively, and the total experimental hydrogen consumption is 539μmol/g, which is also larger than the total theoretical hydrogen consumption of 350μmol/g, in which supposing PtO2 and RuO2 are completely reduced into Pt and Ru respectively. The reduction peak at 87°C can be attributed to the reduction of well-dispersed RuO x , while the other peaks should be assigned to the co-reduction of RuO x , PtO x and Pt/Ru–O–Ce [35]. These results show that the addition of Ru in Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ enhances hydrogen consumption and decreases the reduction temperature of Pt, which are beneficial for improvement of NSR performances. 3.6 XPS analysis The influences of Ru addition on surface element distribution and oxidation state of cerium were investigated by XPS. XPS spectra of Pt 4f and Ru 3d are difficult to be provided because XPS spectra of Pt 4f are almost completely masked by Al 2p spectra [36], while Ru 3d spectra are overlapped by C 1s spectra [37], thus, Ce 3d XPS spectra were investigated. As shown in Fig. 5a, only peak of Ce3+ was observed in XPS spectra of Ce 3d for Pt/Ba/ACZ and Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ, which is probably attributed to the reduction of Pt/Ba/ACZ and Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ at 500°C. Some investigations also show that Ce 3d XPS spectrum can be covered by strong Auger-electron spectrum of barium [38]. To avoid the disturbance of Ba and clarify surface information, Ce 3d XPS spectra of Pt/ACZ and Pt–Ru/ACZ were investigated. As shown in Fig. 5, the curves of Ce 3d spectra are fitted with eight peaks corresponding to four pairs of spin-orbit doublets [29]. Ce 3d3/2 and Ce 3d5/2 spin-orbit components are labeled as U and V, respectively. The peaks of U′ and V′ are assigned to Ce3+species, while the other peaks are attributed to Ce4+species. The proportion of Ce3+ with regard to total cerium was calculated from the ratio of the sum of areas of Ce3+ species to the sum of areas of total ceria species [39]. The surface elemental contents calculated from the normalized peak areas of Ce 3d and Zr 3d are listed in Table 1, surface Ce/Zr atomic ratios in Pt/ACZ and Pt–Ru/ACZ are 0.41 and 0.52, respectively, which are comparable with the theoretical atomic ratio of 0.5. Obviously, surface cerium is richer in ceria–zirconia solid solution of Pt–Ru/ACZ than that of Pt/ACZ, indicating that the addition of Ru leads to the rearrangement of surface atoms [40]. 3.7 in situ DRIFTS In order to figure out NO x storage pathways, in situ DRIFTS experiments of Pt/Ba/ACZ and Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ were carried out at 200°C. As shown in Fig. 6 , after Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ and Pt/Ba/ACZ were exposed to NO/O2 balanced by N2 for 5min, two obvious bands around 1411 and 1325cm−1 were observed, which are assigned to bidentate nitrates and monodentate nitrates, respectively [41]. Besides, an additional weak monodentate nitrate band at 1458cm−1 also appears in Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ [24]. With lengthening of the exposure time, the bands gradually increase, especially for the band around 1325cm−1. However, a band of the bridging nitrite at 1228cm−1 [31] gradually diminishes until completely disappears at 40 and 20min, respectively, meanwhile, a new band of the bridging nitrate around 1550cm−1 appears, its intensity gradually enhances as exposure time increases [31]. The result demonstrates that pre-formed nitrites are transformed into more stable nitrates in Pt/Ba/ACZ and Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ. NO x storage route is correlated with temperature (Fig. 7 ). The strong peak of the bridging nitrite around 1228cm−1 is observed at 50°C. When the temperature rose to 100°C, the intensity of the peak in Pt/Ba/ACZ increases while the peak in Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ weakens, it disappears in Pt/Ba/ACZ and Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ at 250°C and 200°C, respectively. At the same time, the bands of nitrates around 1325 and 1411cm−1 begin to appear at 150°C for Pt/Ba/ACZ and 50°C for Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ, and become stronger and stronger as temperature elevates, indicating the transformation of nitrite to nitrate species. As a result, NO x storage process should mainly proceed via nitrite route below 200°C for Pt/Ba/ACZ and below 100°C for Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ. Subsequently, the NO x storage process gradually changes into nitrate route with the increment of temperature. These results demonstrate that the addition of Ru has an important effect on NO x storage routes due to the different oxidation ability of nitrites to nitrates. 4 Conclusions Pt-based and Pt–Ru-based catalysts were prepared using alumina–ceria–zirconia as a support and were used for NSR. The addition of Ru in Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ enhances NO x storage capacity and promotes NO x reduction in comparison with Pt/Ba/ACZ. The reduction temperature of Pt and the transformation temperature of NO x storage route from nitrite to nitrate are decreased. As a result, Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ shows superior NSR performances to Pt/Ba/ACZ. In summary, this study has demonstrated that the doping of Ru into Pt-based catalysts is a promising approach to promote NSR performances. coredata.dc:description: An effective catalyst of NO x storage and reduction (NSR), Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ (ACZ=Al2O3–Ce0.33Zr0.67O2), has been presented through using ACZ as a support. The catalyst was well characterized by XRD, TEM, N2 physisorption, H2-TPR and XPS. Ce0.33Zr0.67 solid solution was formed in the catalyst. The effects of Ru addition on NSR performances were investigated. In comparison with Pt/Ba/ACZ, the addition of Ru in Pt–Ru/Ba/ACZ drops the reduction temperature of Pt, an obvious promoting effect on NSR was observed above 200°C. The presence of 5vol% CO2 in feed gas shows an inhibiting effect on NO x storage and reduction.
coredata.dc:title: Pt–Ru/Ba/Al2O3–Ce0.33Zr0.67O2: An effective catalyst for NO x storage and reduction
